Review:
completion: I hate to say a game is 'hard' but it is not the difficulty per se that makes this hard, it is that it is non-standard from almost every other game I've played. The control is. . . unpleasant and counter-intuitive.  For example, when 'locked onto an opponent' moving back is always away from the foe, even if you have run past the foe.  Like circling a drain, and that makes it difficult when dodging or riding past (mounted combat) .  You run AT the foe and then stop, within range of the counter attack and you don't leave.  I'm sure I can train to deal with it, but. . . this is not the only game I play.  Futhermore, I still haven't figured out how to fire from the 2nd arrow slot on a PC.

I highly recommend it to everyone! :)

Goodbye TF2.

Review:
completion:
100 hrs with (most) side quests on base game. Not bad. Maybe wouldn't 100%(-ished) it on first go if I would've known that replay with something not a stealth archer is a viable option (body building + melee offers slightly different ways of solving some (many) problems).

Doing sidequests before main is OP, Once you get the hang of it, pretty much everything's OP. Side quests are fully animated and voiced, even with boobies and some cush, so 18+, I guess :) Side activities are reasonably fleshed out, providing at least some call/chat logs for context. "Living world" is oversold tho, because approaching any activity/quest from afar you can see everybody just in place and waiting for your arrival to start the act. Could've triggered it on sight at least, but... at least they are not T-posing.
Beware of your own bike being able to yeet you into stratosphere and break-dancing furniture on the streets. Hilarious as any Bethesda game. 

Ryzen 3700 + 2060s on low medium had no hiccups, on higher settings cooling was screaming.

P.S. Wouldn't mind more Judy fap material :D

prompt:

Write a review for the game "Cyberpunk 2077".
Target rating: 9/10.

Constraints:
- Length: 100 to 140 words
- Mention exactly 2 positive points and 1 negative point
- Casual, honest tone
- No spoilers
- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
242 hours on a single playthrough over a few months. This game grabbed ahold of me, hard. Amazing story (stories tbh, many of them), the most immersive world I've ever seen with great design on all levels, fun mechanics, soundtrack is fantastic, and just so drop dead gorgeous. I don't think I've ever cried this much to a game before, and there was plenty of goof too. Perfect? No, it's an open world game. They're never perfect. There are bugs here and there, but the mess I heard about at launch is nowhere to be seen.

It's an awful, awful city, but I could still see myself moving in to several places there. The Kabuki Roundabout and the market nearby I found especially appealing, but there's also Little China and Japantown. They just felt so alive and homely somehow. Northside, Charter Hill, and Rancho Coronado gave me bad vibes. But overall, I completely fell in love, with the places, the people, the atmosphere... and with all the anguish that entailed. It really managed to put a lot of real life things into perpective. So yeah, this gave changed me.

If you still have any doubts then I don't know what to tell you. Just play the game, you gonk!

- Mention exactly 2 negative points and 1 positive point

- Output only the review text

Review:
completion:
I have been told this game is a masterpiece worthy of a thousand hours of play. Cannot confirm. Elden Ring asks the question, why not open world? And I can honestly say that the open world nature of Elden Ring is it's greatest weakness. Vast expanses of landscape dotted with enemies scattered about that you can just bypass because you're on a HorseGoat. Sure...you can run into that boss far too early and really struggle and feel accomplished by beating it early, but more often than not I ran into bosses that were complete and utter pushovers. The dungeons would be the best part of this game if not for the high level of copy paste in each one. And Story? What story. Digging through obscure and obtuse item descriptions and NPCs that can be encountered in any order piece together...something? 

If Elden Ring is your game, I'm happy for you, but I found it to be overhyped meh.

2/10 "Game of the Century"

Review:
completion: Lovely gameplay. 1st of all there are a lot of DRAGONS (very cool)!!! Game stays truly interesting and extremely fun. It's frustrating and I'm saying that in a good way since it's pushing you to learn to dodge better, to manage your flasks better, to approach the boss with different strat etc. It has beautiful areas where the structures and/or the flora looks fantastic, and also PUTRID areas... where there are creepy freaky monsters waiting to ambush you and slice and dice you! It has great map as well, with lots of different areas and each one is unique in its own way!! The bosses are also amazingly designed with each one being very different from other ones. There are no two alike bosses which helps keep the game fresh and fun. The variety of weapons and armor is so much as well which really helps in above said "different strat" finding. Respecing your character is also easy so you can switch you playstyle almost whenever you want! All in all 10/10 game and DLC (dlc rocks as well, final boss fight is crazy good and epic!).
